p: Tryparsamide started to be used in the mid-1920s, and was administered in series of weekly intravenous injections (with varying regimens). HAT campaigns peaked earlier than syphilis and yaws treatments, i.e., nearer to the calculated tMRCAs of HIV-1 groups M and O [ 26, 27, 28, 29, 30]. In Cameroon, they had a sharp peak in 1926–1928 ( Figure 2), when Eugene Jamot started more organized campaigns based on mobile teams that visited most of the population [ 50, 115, 116, 117, 118]. A few years later, similar teams were put in place in AEF [ 72, 119]. Review articles about these organized campaigns of French Cameroon and AEF show that each patient received 15–24 injections, spread over a period of treatment of two or more years. More than half of the injections were of the cheaper and non-intravenous atoxyl [ 115, 116, 120].
